awd_titl_txt: Engineering a secretion-based, high-titer protein production process in bacteria
awd_abstract_narration:
Protein production is a growing, multi-billion dollar industry that supplies tailored enzymes, such as those used in pharmaceuticals, detergents, textile manufacturing, and environmentally-friendly chemical production. New methods, utilizing bacteria as "protein factories", have the potential to dramatically reduce manufacturing costs and the development time for new protein products. A critical barrier to realizing these benefits is identification of a cost-effective way to separate desired functional proteins from the remaining contents of their host cells. Secreting protein products directly out of the cell is a promising method toward this goal. This work proposes to engineer a protein secretion system in a laboratory strain of bacteria, Salmonella enterica, for efficient and low-cost production of proteins. Success would produce a path for agile design and production of proteins for a number of industries. Moreover, this work will train students at all levels for careers in biotechnology, as the investigators will participate in programs bringing cutting-edge science related to this work to the general public via museums, community talks, and science festivals. 

Controlled transport of proteins from the inside of the cell to the outside is a challenge that nature has overcome in several ways, but that scientists have yet to fully explore. This proposal focuses on engineering the type III secretion system of Salmonella enterica to secrete non-native proteins at high quantity and low cost. The specific objectives are to 1) increase the protein yields achieved with bacterial production and secretion, 2) optimize control over the secretion process to enable scale up to industrial scales, and 3) develop a suite of molecular biology tools for the high-throughput production of a broad set of proteins. Transforming the type III secretion system to enable efficient production of desired proteins will improve understanding of the mechanisms governing this process. Such information is critical not only to molecular biologists as they construct a detailed picture of cellular function, but also to synthetic biologists who wish to engineer organisms with greater levels of complexity and extracellular interaction than previously possible. This work will result in new constructs, protocols, and strains to be shared with other scientists for protein production at both the industrial and research scales.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This work set out to engineer the Type 3 Secretion System (T3SS) of Gram-negative bacteria such as Salmonella typhimurium to enable the secretion of biotechnologically relevant heterologous proteins at high titers. Gram-negative bacteria are advantageous as protein production strains because of their genetic tractability and fast, robust growth in large cultures. However, these strains retain the product intracellularly and require lysis and a complicated purification scheme to recover the product. Secreting the product obviates the need for lysis, thus simplifying the downstream purification and recovery requirements. Utilizing a secretion-enabled bacterial production strain could therefore result in a cheaper and more efficient protein production process. The T3SS is a proteinaceous cellular appendage which can translocate proteins from the cytosol into the extracellular space in one step. Previously, researchers have successfully secreted heterologous proteins via the T3SS, but the secreted protein titer was typically too low for commercial purposes. Therefore, the researchers supported by this grant undertook a variety of strategies to engineer their S. typhimurium secretion strain to increase secretion titers. Accomplishments include engineering the protein monomer which compromises the T3SS needle to develop high-secreting variants, identifying media components which enhance secretion titer, and developing new secretion tags which increase secretion efficiency. Researchers also engineered the cellular regulation of the T3SS, employing both local and global strategies to maximize and maintain the activation of the system, eliminate T3SS repression, and remove unnecessary genetic elements. The result of these efforts is multiple S. typhimurium strains capable of secreting a variety of model and biotechnologically relevant proteins at titers in the hundreds of milligrams per liter. A secretion assay based on a de novo fluorescent reporter was also developed to increase the scale and speed of future engineering efforts.

 

In addition to these technical achievements, the PI and her team were able to present this work to scientific and lay audiences alike at conferences and meetings locally, nationally, and internationally. This includes talks at multiple high schools with primarily underrepresented minority (URM) students who are interested in pursuing scientific careers. The PI was also interviewed about this project for the Tumble Science Podcast for Kids, which reached >40,000 subscribers along with their children. Moreover, ten graduate students, including four PhD candidates and six master students, were trained over the course of this project. The research team mentored an additional eight undergraduate students from universities around the country to carry out hands-on research related to this project.  

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2021
Modified by: Danielle Tullman Ercek
